results.name: Acorus americanus
results.description: Acorus americanus  &amp;#40;Sweet Flag&amp;#41; matures to 2' in height. It prefers wet to wet-mesic soil conditions, growing best in full sun. It can tolerate partial water emersion so would make a good choice for shoreline restorations or pond edges.&amp;amp;nbsp;&amp;amp;nbsp;    Muskrats often eat the roots of  Acorus americanus , seemingly attracted by the cinnamon-like scent. Emerging directly from the roots, the stemless leaves of Sweet Flag are sword-shaped and a colony of them may look like Cattails or Iris leaves from a distance. Green-yellow flowers protrude in cylindrical arcs in mid-summer.    Other common names include Calamus Root, Flag Root, Muskrat Root, Sweet Calomel, and Sweet Sedge. The &amp;quot;Sweet&amp;quot; in the name comes from the sweet aroma the leaves give when broken. Traditionally all  Acorus  plants in North America were called  Acorus calamus , but that name should be restricted to the Eurasian species, which has been introduced to North America.&amp;amp;nbsp; It is thought that Native Americans played a role in the distrubution of this plant since they likely traveled with and traded it; the root was prized as a medicinal remedy for common things like nausea, colds, and heartburn.     Dormant bare root plants ship each year during optimal transplanting season: Fall &amp;#40;October&amp;#41; or Spring &amp;#40;April/May&amp;#41;.

results.name: Actaea pachypoda
results.description: White Baneberry or Doll’s Eyes has very prominent foliage and alarmingly white berries that replace the white cluster of fragrant flowers. Persisting for four to six weeks in late summer to early fall, the berries extend from the stem on thick, reddish stalks. The berries turn bright white when they are mature and the petticule and raceme become a vivid red to complement them. The dark dot at the outer end of the berries from the previous stigma makes it appear to be an eye similar to the china eyes used in dolls. The berries are not edible and are poisonous, just like other fruit in the baneberry family, they should never be consumed. This plant thrives in mottled sunlight or medium shade and its preferred habitat is moist to mesic conditions. When in excessive sunlight the leaves turn yellowish.&amp;amp;nbsp;     The Ruffed Grouse, Yellow-Bellied Sapsucker, and American Robin will come to eat the berries in sparse visits. This plant does not provide any benefit to mammalian species because of its poisonous nature.&amp;amp;nbsp;      *This species may be difficult and/or slow to germinate and grow to maturity. Please note the germination code.&amp;amp;nbsp;Seed of this species is kept under refrigeration &amp;#40;33-38 F&amp;#41; in our warehouse.&amp;amp;nbsp; A few days in transit to you in colder or warmer conditions won’t harm the seed, but it should be put back in refrigeration until you are ready to plant or apply pre-sowing treatment.

results.name: Actaea rubra
results.description: Red Baneberry, &amp;#40;Actaea rubra&amp;#41;, is a favorite species of cool shade gardens and has grand, alluring foliage. Red Baneberry bears fluffy clusters of small white flowers in spring. After flowering, the Red Baneberry still produces color with the berries that ensue in mid to late summer. They are brilliant red, though sometimes white, without the characteristic dark spot of   Actaea pachypoda  &amp;#40;Doll's Eyes&amp;#41; .&amp;amp;nbsp;Baneberry plants are poisonous and should never be eaten.       The berries are nontoxic to birds, the primary disperser of these seeds. Some birds that are attracted to Actaea rubra are Ruffed Grouse, Yellow-bellied Sapsucker, American Robin, Wood Thrush, Gray-cheeked Thrush, and Brown Thrasher. Red Baneberry is avoided by mammalian species because of its toxicity.     *This species may be difficult and/or slow to germinate and grow to maturity.&amp;amp;nbsp; Please note the germination code.&amp;amp;nbsp;  Seed of this species is kept under refrigeration &amp;#40;33-38 F&amp;#41; in our warehouse.&amp;amp;nbsp; A few days in transit to you in colder or warmer conditions won’t harm the seed, but it should be put back in refrigeration until you are ready to plant or apply pre-sowing treatment.      Dormant bare root plants ship each year during optimal transplanting season: Fall &amp;#40;October&amp;#41; or Spring &amp;#40;April/May&amp;#41;.

results.name: Agalinis aspera
results.description: This annual thrives in dry, sandy prairie environments. Rough False Foxglove earned its common name from the short stiff hairs on the stem and upper halves of the leaves. Rarely growing in clusters, it can sometimes be difficult to spot in a prairie, especially if it’s only 8 inches tall at the lower end of its height range. It has showy tubular flowers up to 1-inch long that vary between pink and purple with a red spotted, pale pink throat. Members of the   Agalinis   genus serve as a food source for the larvae of the Common Buckeye butterfly. Like the other False Foxgloves, Rough False Foxglove is partially parasitic on the roots of other plants.

results.name: Agalinis auriculata
results.description: Ear-leaf False Foxglove prefers the environment of a recently disturbed prairie, e.g. one that has undergone prescribed burning.  As an annual, it may not be seen in the same place each year and may not appear at all in some years.  However, because the species persists in the seed bank, it has the potential to return when conditions are more favorable.  This species of False Foxglove, is noted for its purplish foliage and the earlobe-like basal lobes occurring on some leaves. It is listed as endangered in several states.  Members of the   Agalinis   genus serve as a food source for the larvae of the Common Buckeye butterfly.  Like the other False Foxgloves, Ear-leaf False Foxglove is partially parasitic on the roots of other plants.     Also called:  Tomanthera auriculata  and  Gerardia auriculata

results.name: Agalinis tenuifolia
results.description: Narrow leaves that trend toward purple in the fall earned Slender False Foxglove, or Slender Gerardia, its name. Its flower shape stands out from the other false foxgloves with two petals forming a hood and the other three flaring out. This annual prefers slightly disturbed habitats, but beyond that it's flexible about soil, moisture, and sun conditions. Members of the Agalinis genus serve as a food source for the larvae of the Common Buckeye butterfly. &amp;amp;nbsp;Like the other False Foxgloves, Slender False Foxglove is partially parasitic on the roots of other plants.

results.name: Agastache foeniculum
results.description: Anise Hyssop has very showy flowers, fragrant foliage and seems to be of little interest to deer. It self-seeds readily and often blooms the first year. New seedlings are hardy and can be transplanted easily. It's a bee, hummingbird, and butterfly magnet and makes an excellent addition to herb gardens, borders, perennial gardens, and prairies. When the leaves of the Anise Hyssop are crushed they smell like licorice and have been used to make tea and cold remedies.&amp;amp;nbsp; Other common names in use: Lavender Hyssop or Blue Giant Hyssop.   Spring &amp;amp;nbsp;potted plants &amp;#40;3-packs and trays of 38&amp;#41; ship when all plants are well-rooted and transit-ready, early May through June.&amp;amp;nbsp;&amp;amp;nbsp; Fall&amp;amp;nbsp; potted plants &amp;#40;3-packs&amp;#41; ship when all plants are well-rooted and transit-ready, late August through September.     This species is also available as part of a 9-plant&amp;amp;nbsp;    Pollinator Power Pack &amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;#40;spring or fall&amp;#41; or 38-plant&amp;amp;nbsp;    Mix &amp;amp;amp; Match Tray  &amp;amp;nbsp;&amp;#40;spring only&amp;#41;.

results.name: Agastache nepetoides
results.description: A robust grower, the sharply four-sided stem of Yellow Giant Hyssop reaches heights from three to eight feet. In late summer its branching top is crowned by a long cylindrical spike of clustered yellow to yellow-green flowers.  This favorite of bees, butterflies, and other pollinators prefers growing in rich, open woodlands.  While the leaves don’t have a strong smell like other species in the mint family, the bitterness of its leaves make it deer resistant.

results.name: Agastache scrophulariifolia
results.description: This vigorous plant features opposing leaves and tall, strong central stems. The flowers of Purple Giant Hyssop are very pale purple--not purple-looking at all from a distance. They open slowly over a period of weeks. The long bloom time in combination with their being nectar-rich makes them highly attractive to butterflies and other pollinators, including the federally-endangered Rusty Patched Bumble Bee &amp;#40;see photo&amp;#41;. Birds also feed on the seeds that follow. Sensitive to competition, Purple Giant Hyssop requires some habitat disturbance to persist in an area over time. In several eastern states, it is listed as threatened or endangered.   Potted plants &amp;#40;trays of 38&amp;#41; ship when all plants are well-rooted and transit-ready, early May through June.&amp;amp;nbsp;   Click here if you prefer to mix/match up to 6 species in a tray.

hierarchy: Plants to Grow Under Black Walnut Trees
results.name: Ageratina altissima
results.description: Common to woodland edges and recently-disturbed shaded sites,  Ageratina altissima  reaches 2-4’ in height on strong, branching stems. In late summer to fall, pure white flowers appear in flat-topped, branching clusters. The leaves are long, large-toothed and somewhat heart-shaped on long stems. Immediately after soil disturbance, its onset may seem weedy, but it will settle down and grow well with other plants.   White Snakeroot contains the toxin tremetol, responsible for “milk sickness,” which caused problems for the livestock of early European settlers and killed Abraham Lincoln’s mother in 1818. It is usually avoided by mammalian herbivores because of its bitter foliage. In overgrazed areas it may be consumed by cattle or horses, which can prove fatal. Its flowers attract a variety of insects including bees, butterflies and moths. A number of caterpillars are also known to feed on the foliage.  It was formerly classified as  Eupatorium rugosum .

results.name: Agoseris cuspidata
results.description: A deep tap root to tolerate drought and naturally dry conditions, short stature &amp;#40;1' max&amp;#41; and a long bloom time make the Prairie Dandelion perfect for landscaping, rock gardens, and drier prairies. Grass-like leaves make it readily distinguishable from its weedy cousin  Taraxacum officinale . Its preference for well-drained areas is one factor that renders it a non-aggressive species.&amp;amp;nbsp;    The bright yellow flowers attract many bees, especially bumblebees. The foliage is not usually consumed by mammalian herbivores. Prairie Dandelion seeds look very similar to the common lawn weed,&amp;amp;nbsp; Taraxacum officinale,  and spread via wind.&amp;amp;nbsp;&amp;amp;nbsp;    It is also called   Nothocalais cuspidata  and  Microseris cuspidata.

results.name: Agrimonia gryposepala
results.description: Tall Hairy Agrimony is a perennial that grows to be up to 5 feet tall. Its root system is fibrous and rhizomatous. If sun is not an option where you are planting, no worries! Tall Hairy Agrimony thrives in partly shaded areas and most soils. In its native range, you can find Tall Hairy Agrimony in upland savannas, woodlands, soggy meadows, and swamps.&amp;amp;nbsp;  Typically blooming in July and August, Tall Hairy Agrimony &amp;#40; Agrimonia gryposepala &amp;#41; produces small yellow flowers consisting of 5 petals and 5-10 stamens.&amp;amp;nbsp;The stamen tops are a rust color, complimenting the yellow petals. These flowers are mainly pollinated by bees. The leaves of this  Agrimonia  follow a pinnation pattern.&amp;amp;nbsp;&amp;amp;nbsp;

results.name: Agrimonia striata
results.description: Roadside Agrimony  &amp;#40;Agrimonia striata&amp;#41;&amp;amp;nbsp; reaches a maximum height of 6 feet, but most plants will be 4-5 feet.&amp;amp;nbsp; Roadside Agrimony prefers a terrestrial habitat, flourishing in meadows, fields, and woodland edges. The leaves follow a compound alternate structure, with jagged teeth like edges on the leaf blades. Like many other  Agrimonia , Roadside Agrimony consists of 5 yellow petals. This perennial will bloom most profusely in July. It prefers to reside in partly shaded areas and requires a medium amount of water.

results.name: Alisma subcordatum
results.description: Mud Plantain is also called American Water Plaintain and Alisma plantago-aquatica.&amp;amp;nbsp; It sends up a flowering stem from their clumped base leaves. The small flowers have white or pink-tinged petals. Ribbon-like leaves formed underwater rarely are seen on adult plants because they tend to rot.&amp;amp;nbsp; A typical emergent aquatic plant, Mud Plantain's lower part is often below water while its upper part is exposed.

results.name: Alisma triviale
results.description: The oval basal leaves of Alisma triviale are about one-foot tall and form a rosette from which rises a whorled panicle of small white flowers, reaching a height of three feet during summer.&amp;amp;nbsp; This species prefers full or partial sun and mucky soil or shallow, slow-moving, even stagnant water.&amp;amp;nbsp; It withstands drought better than most aquatic plants.&amp;amp;nbsp; Other Common Names in use: Northern Water Plantain.

results.name: Allium canadense
results.description: The seed we sell are actually the top-set bulbs &amp;#40;see corresponding photo&amp;#41;.  Allium canadense  matures to 18&amp;quot; in height and has light pink to pink flowers.&amp;amp;nbsp; It is a very versatile plant doing well in almost every sun and soil type: medium-wet through dry soil conditions and full sun to full shade.    The bulbs of Wild Garlic are edible and can be applied to insect stings.&amp;amp;nbsp; Making tea from the bulb has been used to control coughs and vomiting. Smaller bees are very important pollinators of the Wild Garlic's flowers. Rabbits and deer tend to avoid eating all the  Allium  species due to the onion scent and the spicy taste of the foliage.  Allium canadense  attracts hummingbirds, butterflies and bees.&amp;amp;nbsp; Other common names include Meadow Garlic and Wild Onion.&amp;amp;nbsp;        Seed of this species is kept under refrigeration &amp;#40;33-38 F&amp;#41; in our warehouse.&amp;amp;nbsp; A few days in transit to you in colder or warmer conditions won’t harm the seed, but it should be put back in refrigeration until you are ready to plant or apply pre-sowing treatment.     Dormant bare root plants ship each year during optimal transplanting season: Fall &amp;#40;October&amp;#41; and Summer &amp;#40;July&amp;#41; shipping.

results.name: Allium canadense var. lavendulare
results.description: Unlike our other  Wild Garlic , Showy Wild Garlic boasts a large cluster of white to pink flowers in late spring.  While its flowers attract bees and butterflies, the sharp taste of its foliage makes it deer resistant.  Showy Wild Garlic foliage and bulbs are edible, but they taste more like an onion than like commonly sold garlic cultivars.  It is drought tolerant and prefers well-drained soils in full sun.  Plants spread by bulb offshoots and seed.   Dormant bare root plants ship each year during optimal transplanting season: Fall &amp;#40;October&amp;#41; or Spring &amp;#40;April/May&amp;#41;.

results.name: Allium cernuum
results.description: Nodding Onion is stunning to have in gardens because of its unique flowers. A ball of star-like flowers forms on each stem, tending to bend downward; hence the name &amp;quot;nodding&amp;quot; onion.&amp;amp;nbsp; The nodding habit may also protect the nectar from rain.    Native American tribes used the bulbs of Nodding Onion as a treatment for croup, colic, colds and fevers.&amp;amp;nbsp;  Allium cernuum  blooms in midsummer, and the flowers are pollinated by small short-tongued bees, such as Halictid bees.&amp;amp;nbsp; Nodding Onion, like all the  Allium  species, is deer-resistant.     Allium cernuum  grows best in full or partial sun, and moist to medium conditions.&amp;amp;nbsp; It tends to spread by seed and bulb offshoots.&amp;amp;nbsp; The flowers are almost white to shades of purple in color and mature plants can reach up to 18&amp;quot; in height.&amp;amp;nbsp; This plant is easy to grow, and will spread gradually under suitable conditions.      Dormant bare root plants ship each year during optimal transplanting season: Fall &amp;#40;October&amp;#41; or Spring &amp;#40;April/May&amp;#41;

results.name: Allium stellatum
results.description: Well-suited to rock gardens and dry-mesic areas like rock outcroppings, Prairie Onion prefers full sun and dry conditions. The root system of Prairie Onion consists of a single bulb with deep secondary roots. This deep root system allows Prairie Onion to easily survive droughts. It does not compete well with tall, aggressive plants.&amp;amp;nbsp;    The light pink, white, or lavender flowers are shaped like small stars. These flowers bloom for about 3 weeks. Small bees are the main pollinator. This plant has an onion-like scent, which makes it an undesirable food source to most mammals, including deer and rabbits.&amp;amp;nbsp;     Prairie Onion is similar to its cousin&amp;amp;nbsp; Nodding Onion , except for its solid, upright stem and stature.&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp;It is easy to grow from seed but may take many years for a flowering plant - for this reason it may be best to buy a few roots as they respond to yearly bulb divisions well.&amp;amp;nbsp; Most of the&amp;amp;nbsp; Allium&amp;amp;nbsp; species are edible.&amp;amp;nbsp; Other common names include: Autumn Onion, Wild Onion or Cliff Onion.        Dormant bare root plants ship each year during optimal transplanting season: Fall &amp;#40;October&amp;#41; or Spring &amp;#40;April/May&amp;#41;

hierarchy: Plants to Grow Under Black Walnut Trees
results.name: Allium tricoccum
results.description: Wild Leeks, also known as “Ramps”, are popular among urban foodies and foragers alike.&amp;amp;nbsp; Although plentiful in some areas, Wild Leeks face the same pressures as other woodland plants, such as encroachment by invasive species, development and over-collection. If foraging for Wild Leeks, or other woodland natives, remember to harvest sustainably as they are very, very slow to reproduce. From successful seed germination to ramp harvest can be 5-7 years. There is plenty of flavor in the leaves alone. Clipping a few leaves instead of digging the bulb will ensure that a patch of Wild Leeks can thrive while being enjoyed.     Wild Leek prefers typical woodland conditions: medium wet to medium dry soil and full to partial shade. It has reddish stalks reaching heights of 8&amp;quot; in the spring. The early foliage dies back late spring before the white to creamy-white flowers appear in June or July.&amp;amp;nbsp; The seeds of  Allium tricoccum  will bounce when dropped onto a hard surface; a seed dispersal mechanism of the plant.    *This species &amp;#40;in seed&amp;#41; may be difficult and/or slow to germinate and grow to maturity.&amp;amp;nbsp; Please note the germination code, right.     Dormant bare root plants ship each year during optimal transplanting season: Fall &amp;#40;October&amp;#41; or Spring &amp;#40;April/May&amp;#41;.

results.name: Alnus incana subsp. rugosa
results.description: Speckled Alder spreads rhizomatously and prefers moderately acidic soil in low, moist areas, often along streams and lakes.  This large shrub earned its subspecies name from the wrinkled or rugose leaves.  Frequently forming dense thickets, it is fast growing and sometimes aggressive in open fens and bogs.      It serves as a food source for many species: deer and beavers eat the bark, goldfinches eat the seeds, its leaves host the larvae of the green comma butterfly, and the larvae of the harvester butterfly eat the woolly aphids often found on this species.  Alder shrubs also have a symbiotic relationship with bacteria in the Frankia genus, the nodules on their roots a visual reminder.     It is also called Tag Alder,  Alnus rugosa , and Hazel Alder.  IL lists it as endangered.

results.name: Ammannia coccinea
results.description: New!&amp;amp;nbsp; &amp;amp;nbsp; Ammannia coccinea , Scarlet toothcup, is an annual in the loosestrife family that gets its name from the appearance of its fruit when ripe. The lower leaves hold 3-5 flowers per axil that range in color from pink to purple. Their flowers attract several butterflies seeking nectar, including the Eastern Tailed-Blue and Checkered White. It is also an important waterfowl food source. Scarlet toothcup can be aggressive in favorable locations such as muddy soils along ponds, river banks, and grassy areas that experience flooding.

results.name: Amorpha canescens
results.description: Growing in shrubs up to three feet tall, Lead Plant is topped by spike-like masses of tiny purple blossoms. Each flower has a single 1/4&amp;quot;-long petal curling around 10 orange-tipped stamens.&amp;amp;nbsp; It prefers full sun but will tolerate part shade.&amp;amp;nbsp; The branches will reach for light in partial shade conditions however, giving it a more sprawling form with less flowers.&amp;amp;nbsp; It is not picky about soil type, and will grow in all types of medium to very dry sandy, gravel, loam, and clay.&amp;amp;nbsp; Abundant bees, butterflies, moths, beetles and other beneficial insects will be attracted to Lead Plant. In addition to the many different pollinators, Lead Plant is one of the larval hosts of the Dog Face Sulphur, also known as  Southern Dogface .    The plant's tough roots made pioneer plowing difficult, causing early Settlers to dub it &amp;quot;Devil's Shoestrings.&amp;quot;&amp;amp;nbsp; Other speculative accounts about its common name credit the dusky hue of the foliage or an old belief that the plant's presence was an indicator of sub-surface lead ore.     Its deep roots enable the plant to survive prairie fires and times of drought.&amp;amp;nbsp; After very tough winters, it may die back to the ground but the extreme long-lived nature of Lead Plant and its deep tap root will usually allow it to recover.&amp;amp;nbsp; It can be late to leaf out compared to other shrubs and trees, especially in northern climates, so be patient.      Species of genus Amorpha are legumes. Most legume species harbor beneficial bacteria called rhizobia on their roots.&amp;amp;nbsp;  Genus-specific strains of this bacterium called inoculum can aid in the fixation of atmospheric nitrogen and improve long-term health of native plant communities. Inoculum is naturally-occurring in most soils and additional amendment is usually not needed. However, in low fertility soils it may be necessary. Genus-specific strains are available at    prairiemoon.com/inoculum                To properly inoculate your legume seed prior to planting, follow Germination Code I.&amp;amp;nbsp;&amp;amp;nbsp;       Fall Potted Plants  &amp;#40;3-packs&amp;#41; ship when all plants arewell-rooted and transit-ready: &amp;#40;LateAugust - September&amp;#41;

results.name: Amorpha fruticosa
results.description: With most of its foliage in the upper third of the tall, bushy plant,  Amorpha fruticosa  can form thickets in dense plantings. The genus name is from the Greek for formless or deformed, because the single-petaled flower is unlike most blossoms in the pea family.&amp;amp;nbsp; Other Common Names in use: Desert False Indigo and Indigo Bush.     A vigorous plant throughout its range, this species can beinvasive when planted outside of its historic regions.&amp;amp;nbsp; We are waiting for an updated BONAP map for this species. It is native throughout much of the US but not native in Washington, Maine, New Hampshire, Vermont, Massachusetts, Connecticut, and Rhode Island. It is a prohibited species is Maine and Connecticut. It is an invasive species in Connecticut and Washington. It is also not native in Michigan and the Northwest area of the U.S.     Species of genus Amorpha are legumes. Most legume species harbor beneficial bacteria called rhizobia on their roots.&amp;amp;nbsp;  Genus-specific strains of this bacterium called inoculum can aid in the fixation of atmospheric nitrogen and improve long-term health of native plant communities. Inoculum is naturally-occurring in most soils and additional amendment is usually not needed. However, in low fertility soils it may be necessary. Genus-specific strains are available at&amp;amp;nbsp;   prairiemoon.com/inoculum               To properly inoculate your legume seed prior to planting, follow Germination Code I.&amp;amp;nbsp;&amp;amp;nbsp;  &amp;amp;nbsp;      Dormant bare root plants ship each year during optimal transplanting season: Fall &amp;#40;October&amp;#41; or Spring &amp;#40;April/May&amp;#41;.&amp;amp;nbsp;  Fall 2020:&amp;amp;nbsp;  The bare root shrub is 2 years old and a height of approximately 18&amp;quot;.
